title: Monday, 23rd July, 2018

AHA Capital buy Daikin stock (6367 JP) - world's largest manufact. of air conditioning systems

Ooh, down today. "Trade war" rather than "trade war fears ease". The wax-on wax-off of market reporting.

Truth is, of course, that it's a Monday at the back of July and there's not a lot of actual news around so no one's doing very much.

Alchemy30 morning

We, however, have an hour to fill. So let's get on with it.

SoS is this a pants off day?

Driss lets talk tesla
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Atos, then ...............

Excel Developer @Flaneur: yep
BE11:15am

Buying Syntel for $3.4bn, as had been rumoured approximately everywhere over the past month by every Bandit10-grade random.

BE11:17am

French companies are always a challenge when it comes to reporting M&A, at least if you want to stick by the usual protocols and niceties of not writing stuff that's been denied and suchlike.

Swedish Chef @Driss I see Musk has resolved his farting unicorn problem.
11:17 am
BE11:18am

Anyway, it's now an actual deal and there's not a lot about it that's too exciting. Here's UBS.

Flaneur I see Amazon - the 'tax efficient' king of the gig economy is moaning about Brexit.... 'please dont derail our hollowing-out of your economy for some old Democracy nonsense' not much of a slogan for Remain, is it?Could only get worse for them if Blair wades in again....
BE11:18am

Atos announced the $3.4bn acquisition of Syntel, a c90% US-focused IT Services provider with a large offshore footprint (18k of 23k are in India). The deal values Syntel at 3.5x 2019 consensus Sales and 13.8x EV/EBITDA. Atos plans for $120m in back office savings and sales synergies of $250m, both by the end of 2021. Syntel is expected to be double-digit accretive in 2019 (financing is at less than 2%) and boost Atos’ capabilities in B&PS in the US where Atos has a disappointing -3.9% growth in Q2 within total sales up 1.5% (cons. 2.0%). Over 40% of Syntel's sales come from Fin. Services and c40% is "digital services".

Investor0007 Hi
BE11:18am

Against that you have uninspiring results.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

While European growth was solid (Germany +4.3%, France +1.2%, UK +0.9%) excl. Benelux (-2.4%), the weak US trend pulled growth back, notably in I&DM (H1: -1.7%). A 190% Q2 book-to-bill in the US means guidance is unchanged. H1 margins improved 20bp y/y to 9.1% (cons. 9.1%) as I&DM margins fell 80bp y/y. FCF fell to €180m from €242m last year as working capital deteriorated (€140m outflow vs €37m last year). Mgt noted that May was weak, leading to lower invoicing and cash collection in June. Guidance for 2-3% organic growth (cons. 2.4%) and 10.5-11.0% margins (cons. 10.8%) and 60% FCF conversion (cons. 59%) is unchanged.

BE11:20am

Atos down about 8% live

BE11:21am

Even though the response to the deal is cautiously positive.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Morgan Stanley:

Excel Developer @BE: Is your pricer broken? No prices yet,
Cracklenpop @Noddy BoffinDon't you just love German compound nouns.
ESM @be, why not sergio as pic of the day... poor man market does not even do him the grace of marking stoock massively down to prove his worth. where are you and PM on your very good purchase at the time?
BE11:22am

Solving strategic issues in North America: Firstly, it would help to bolster the group's US scale and bring much needed offshore presence. Syntel has c. $1bn of revenue at a 24% operating margin, critically in areas of SI and consulting which we think the US operations [mainly outsourcing] have lacked and stunted Atos' success there. We believe Atos has struggled to win project work around cloud transformations as it did not have the same brand name it has in Europe - and also lacked offshoring scale to be as cost effective as rivals. Secondly, even though the US offshoring opportunity has matured [much of what can be offshored has been done]

BE11:23am

Syntel would bring more substantial offshoring
capability to the group, which has historically been at the lower end of the peer range [28% in 1H16]. The company also brings expertise in digital [40% of sales]. Syntel saw revenues decline in 2017 (4%) on the back of cuts at a top 3 customer but has returned to growth in 1H18 (growing 9-10%, albeit off a low base). Atos anticipate a run-rate of c. $250m in revenue synergies by 2021, and c. $120m of cost synergies coming in linearly.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

(@ESM: what?)

Excel Developer @ESM: Didn't you used to be EFSF?
Alchemy30 While on M&A, AGK has been ticking up, any further noise ?Thanks
BE11:25am

On the negative side, we think investors may look to the announced deal being more expensive from a valuation point of view - due to its more strategic nature, rather than a very cheap asset which requires heavier restructuring (more the type of deal Atos has completed in the past).

ESM @Excel sorry mate only using my initials. I aint funny enough for ecb related acronyms
BE11:25am

As a result, the planned EPS accretion is more limited. Atos expect double-digit EPS accretion in 2019, rising further as synergies crystallise. On an initial view [taking the Syntel tax rate which may come down if Atos can utilise any tax losses] we see the ROIC from the deal at c. 4% pre cost synergies and c. 6% including all cost synergies in 2019. We would not expect investors to include revenue synergies in these calculations given they
are often offset by integration disruption. In addition, the deal utilises, we think, a large part of Atos' firepower - or more importantly management bandwidth to integrate larger M&A (Syntel and Six payments in Worldline) - which may also be viewed negatively. Although the premium to the prevailing price of c. $39 is small, Syntel has rerated significantly over the last 12-18 months and so we think the true premium is larger than it appears. The purchase multiples is c. 3.8x 2018e EV/sales, 19x EV/EBIT [falling to 12x if we include on a pro forma basis all the cost synergies] and c. 21x P/E.

undefined

(@Alchemy30: no.)

Tesla Inc. has asked some suppliers to refund a portion of what the electric-car company has spent previously, an appeal that reflects the auto maker’s urgency to sustain operations during a critical production period.

The Silicon Valley electric-car company said it is asking its suppliers for cash back to help it become profitable, according to a memo reviewed by The Wall Street Journal that was sent to a supplier last week. Tesla requested the supplier return what it calls a meaningful amount of money of its payments since 2016, according to the memo.

Forester Worrying though Trumps mother of CAPITAL LETTERS war with Iran is....he did the same with Kim and was practical hugging him within weeks and securing a "great deal" [TBC!]......

#REF! for the general auto suppliers (not Panasonic), Tesla is such a low volume buyer, why would they stump up cash for them? I mean, if you are engine agnositc and on low margin Tesla is of low importance to you
Tom Dalgleish 30 degrees? Try 52
Excel Developer @ESM: you gonna get zapped if you accuse Bryce of trading on the tips he gives.

(.......... @ESM: I genuinely don't know what the hell you're talking about.)

11:32 am

I'm losing track here. So Musk has commented on the cancellation thing last week and the farting unicorn thing a week or so ago but not yet on the ..... this thing? It's so damn noisy.

BE11:33am

The cancellation thing was this note from Needham.

Forester @nichoman well I cant see Iran wanting or being able to agree to all the items on Trumps list of demands....but as we know this seems to be his standard negotiating tactic
Tom Dalgleish Boffins of the world unite and save Tesla
BE11:33am

We are downgrading Tesla to Underperform from Hold as we believe the stock is still overvalued despite falling 16% from its June 2017 peak (the S&P 500 is up 15% over the same 56-week period). Our bearish stance assumes: 1) slower sales of Model S/X on increased competition, possible cannibalization from Model 3 and expiration of credits; 2) slower gross margin improvement for Model 3 based on persistently high manufacturing costs, namely low yields; 3) negative impact to gross margin as ZEV credits decline in 2019; 4) lower energy revenue given the recent restructuring and lastly 5) an unsustainable capital structure with a projected $6BN FCF burn through 2020 and a $1.486BN note due in 2019.

Mouselet Tesla is hardly in a position where what's required to save it are boffins
11:34 am
BE11:34am

We increase our delivery assumption for Model 3 and lower OPEX est. related to the restructuring offset by lower energy revenue. Lowering 2019 est. on Model 3 GM, reduced sales of Model S/X: Our 2019 rev/EPS ests. move to $26.3BN/$0.80 vs. $26.6BN/$1.80, below the Street’s $28.1BN/$2.27. We lower our 2019 GM est. to 17.1% vs 17.9% on lower ZEV credit sales (carries 100% GM), margin pressure on Model S/X and slower margin improvement throughout 2019 on Model 3.

Flaneur On US autos... interesting to see Trumps car tariff plans getting a cautious thumbs-up from the UAW of all people.... danger for the Democrats there.... opportunity for Tesla?
A. M. "asking its suppliers for cash back to help it become profitable" -- interesting phrase there.
BE11:34am

Model 3 cancellations have picked up: Based on our checks, refunds are outpacing deposits as cancellations accelerate. The reasons are varied: extended wait times, the expiration of the $7,500 credit, and unavailability of the $35k base model. In August '17, TSLA cited a refund rate of 12%. Almost a year later, we believe it has doubled and outpaced deposits. Model 3 wait times are currently 4-12 months and with base model not available until mid-2019, consumers could wait until 2020. We highlight that nearly 1/3 of cash holdings were customer deposits ($920MM).

Mouselet I think the fact that banks are willing to tell people applying for mortgages with them that they are overpaying is generally a good thing, though it seems sad that the people often seem to carry on with the same purchase anyway
Forester UK supermarkets do the same thing for example, but of course they are negotiating from a position of strength!
BE11:35am

Model S/X sales expect to remain lackluster: TSLA delivered 44.1k models of Model S/X in the 1H18, down 6.3% Y/Y vs. 1H17. Model S deliveries have declined two quarters in a row, -13% Y/Y & -9% Y/Y. We have lowered our Model S/X assumptions for '19 to 50.2k & 49.2k, respectively vs. 54.0k & 56.3k due to intense competition and possible cannibalization from Model 3.

Mouselet ( I got the mortgage approval before starting shopping for houses, used it as the main factor in picking where to look, and offered less than the asking price ... am I odd that way? Or was 2012 a different country where they do things differently )
11:36 am
BE11:36am

There's also a bunch of stuff about ZEV credits, which look very like the old solar-panel subsidies that did for the industry in several countries.

Mouselet Does anyone have figures for how the X sells in comparison to the S? ARM post-takeover has a fair number of S in the car park but not a single X
BE11:36am

In 2019, we believe the supply of ZEV credits will substantially outstrip demand, limiting Tesla’s ability to sell its credits and driving down the price per credit. With the increased volume of Model 3 deliveries, TSLA is generating a sizable amount of ZEV credits, which we believe the company is selling to other car manufacturers. However, we believe the lucrative business could see pricing headwinds, driven by limited demand growth. As a result, we forecast ZEV credits revenue to decline to $633MM in 2019, from $704MM in 2018 and to $400MM in 2020.

ESM @Be send you an email in tad
BE11:37am

Uh, what? Tesla sells its credits to other car makers?

Cracklenpop Any grey on Tesco planning a new discount store format?
11:37 am
BE11:38am

Since Tesla only produces zero-emission vehicles, it earns ZEV credits on every vehicle that it sells, and can sell the excess credits to other manufacturers who are not generating enough to comply with the regulation.

Tom Dalgleish That low yield is interesting although the cars seem reliable once on the road
Excel Developer @Mouselet: I agree you should use the mortgage company's valuation as a negotiating tactic, "Should mate can't offer you more than x"
BE11:38am

....that's .... bad.

undefined
11:38 am
BE11:38am

GSK mentioned earlier.

GlaxoSmithKline PLC (GSK:LSE): Last: 1,562, up 12.38 (+0.80%), High: 1,572, Low: 1,550, Volume: 2.37m
BE11:39am

Post Friday's FT story about the chairman talking about spinoffs.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Response here has been lukewarm.

BE11:40am

There's quite a lot of "why now?"

BE11:41am

Citi has an answer, but it's not pretty.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

We interpret Friday’s FT reporting of the board’s apparent
reassessment of the potential merits for separation of GSK consumer business as an attempt by the Chairman to buy time and support the recently rebounded GSK share-price despite (i) the paucity of needle moving near term pipeline readouts (ii) a still early pipeline (iii) high competitive pressures in key HIV and respiratory franchises (iv) constrained balance sheet

BE11:42am

NVS minority acquisition aside, nothing has changed. A consumer separation was always a strategic option. The Chairman loses little by indicating his openness to contemplate separation. However, investors should note that (i) a strategic review is very different to a commitment to separate (as evidenced by GSK’s aborted separation of ViiV and PFE’s aborted historic breakup) (ii) the “2-3 years’ timeframe” may as well be an eternity. The bottom line is that the potential separation and valuation upside of a spin/ IPO depends on if and when the pharma business outlook is restored to sufficient strength to stand and remain independent. This was always the case.

Flaneur @Mouselet - https://www.howmanyleft.co.uk/?utf8=✓&q=tesla&commit=Search
Swedish Chef Had trouble extending my mortgage recently. 25% LTV, equities of 10x value of loan. Bank would not take account of that or div income, only pension. Bananas!
BE11:43am

Which is an argument we've heard a few times, the gist being that consumer healthcare is both easy cash and a poison pill for GSK's subscale pharma side.

Tom Dalgleish DEB in a death spiral?
Excel Developer @Swedish chef: did you pledge the equities as collateral?
11:44 am
BE11:44am

Splitting them makes sense from a SOTP perspective, though is unlikely to be too great a prospect for management's continuing employment.

BE11:45am

[T]he board will not spin/IPO or sell GSK consumer unless GSK pharma/ vaccine can self-fund its OPEX and has a sufficient outlook and market valuation to preclude potential acquisition. This is a possibility, but not a
certainty. Additional considerations include resolving shared manufacturing and potential OTC switches. We look forward to hearing management’s comments over the FT commentary on their H1 results July 25th but now Pandora’s Box is open to investors, it will prove tough to close.

sprout As an investor in banks I'm somewhat reassured they are not taking equities for house loan collateral.
0627 Ryan air
Excel Developer @sprout: what? take a bigger haircut if necessary, you're turning down business.
BE11:46am

The other attraction to a spinoff would be to load the consumer side up with debt.

Mouselet I would wonder whether selling equities to the value of the loan and then leveraging 11% on the rest of the equities might not put you in a position not much worse than the mortgage
11:47 am
BE11:47am

And it's just not in good enough shape for that. Here's JP Morgan.

Swedish Chef Excel: offered but HSBC didn’t want to know. Sprout: 25% LTV as first line of defence! As HSBC holder I was upset that my bank was rejecting profitable business.
Excel Developer @Mouselet: find a specialist lender IMHO.
BE11:47am

we believe a spin-off of the Consumer division in 2-3 years time could
create some value, unwinding some conglomerate discount. That said, we believe the Pharma business would require significant bolstering of the pipeline ahead of such a spin-off, in order not to see a significant PE de-rating of the ex-Consumer, Pharma/Vaccine stub. As the business currently stands, the GSK ex Consumer stub would have a weak medium-term outlook (1% 2018-21 Core EBIT CAGR), but without the longer-term sustainability provided by the Consumer business post 2021, and hence we believe the stub would be unlikely to maintain the current, almost sector-like PE multiple, at which GSK currently trades (c.13.5x 2019e PE vs. sector on 14.4x 2019e PE). A stub de-rating could therefore offset at least some of the upside to the Consumer business re-rating.

Pseudonym A 25% LTV mortgage is surely about as secure a loan as is possible. If they don't want to carry it, why don't they just ask a higher rate?
Mouselet I agree that 'may I borrow an amount equal to 10% of this pile of capital' is quite close to 'dear bank, may I shift some risk to you, I will not pay you anything for this service'
undefined
Mouselet which you can understand a bank as interpreting as 'this pile of capital may be composed more of miscellaneous aggregate and less of bedrock than advertised'
Pseudonym I suppose there's an element of taking out a loan to gamble on the stock market if you've got equity covering it 10x then you're using the loan to leverage your portfolio.
Mouselet I am very precisely using my mortgage to leverage my portfolio, and am glad HSBC in 2012 let me do that. It's been a good plan.
Swedish Chef Eventually sorted at 1 over. Offset against all other accounts except my 5% regular saver :-)
Mouselet Maintaining a 5% regular saver (which is still effectively a 2.5% term deposit) while having the price of four houses in equities seems kind of cheese-paring
Excel Developer @Mouselet: damn right. good on you sir.

BE11:52am

Ryanair underperforms peers in terms of price developments. In our view,
since 2014, for many investors Ryanair’s equity story has been that as the
airline enters primary airports, where fares are higher than on average in
the Ryanair network, their average fares should be positively impacted.
Despite strong capacity growth in primary airports over 2014-17,
Ryanair’s prices have remained weak, below the performance of its main
peers. We believe more and more investors will start to question Ryanair’s
equity story going forward.

BE11:54am

Or for the flip argument, SocGen.

Excel Developer Not paying off your mortgage fully to fund equities is recommended by the FT's (and formerly BofE MPC member) John Gray. https://www.amazon.co.uk/Long-Short-investment-normally-intelligent/dp/1781256756/ref=pd_lpo_sbs_14_t_0?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=9SDB5C0WWQ6N7X3CH8E7

Excel Developer John Kay sorry
11:54 am
BE11:54am

We think RYA delivered a solid quarter in a difficult environment. It remains to be seen how intensive the strikes will be during the rest of the year. For the time being RYA guides for 2Q unit revenues of +1%, vs a guidance of +4% given in May, due to “the recent weaker fare environment and the expected impact of crew strikes on forward pricing”. The 2Q results beat is worth only 1% on an FY basis, and the outlook for the remainder of the year isn’t too good, which is why we expect no consensus forecast changes.

Pseudonym There's keeping a mix of assets and there's day trading on your house capital. The banks don't really want to be associated with people betting the farm on ALM stock.
